messageBody:
Jon:

In the last few days, I've been trying to learn a little something about fonts and keyboard mapping.  I would be interested in having some information regarding the program you used to develop Jerome?  What is it?  Where is it available?  What does it cost?  And does that same program also set up the keyboard mapping?  If you can briefly shed any light on this, I would appreciate it.  Thanks.

Paige

Jon Zuck wrote:

Great issues Paige, Thanks for your feedback.  Unfortunately, I don't have the time to think about these matters in depth right now.  I'll have to look into it another time, unfortunately I don't know when, but I haven't forgotten. Thanks, Shalom v'Tovah,. Jon
http://surf.to/frimmin It is more necessary to love much than to think much;
always do that which impels you most to love.         --St. Teresa of Avila, The Interior Castle
----- Original Message -----
From: C. Paige Gabhart
To: Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com ; frimmin@...
Sent: Saturday, March 16, 2002 3:07 PM
Subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Remapping Jerome
 Jon:

I had almost completed my response to your attached post when the computer locked up, and I found once again I had neglected to save the file!  If Chevrolets or Fords were this undependable who would buy them?  I have been reviewing your remapping proposal and have made some comments below.  Let me say that I think it is great and on the right track but still needs a little tweaking.

Jon Zuck wrote:

It appears to me that you intend to the DFJK keys to act like the shift key,
to be depressed and held down while the vowel key on the opposite hand is
struck.  It certainly would make more sense to have a "SHIFTy" function
performed by index fingers instead of the poor little pinky, so that is
definitely a noble idea.  Unfortunately, <sigh> it won't work. [snip]
I had reached that conclusion by the time I sent the post that it wouldn't work for the reason you discussed.  But your solution of using a key ("j") as a "flag" to alter the output of the regular key will work just as well as what I had proposed.  I toyed around with the idea of using "f" as a flag for letters typed with the right hand, but "f" can combine with too many other letters to form regular words so I believe your choice of "j" as the single flag for the half-letters and alternate "n" and "x" makes more sense.  The two letter combinations for namer dot should work fine in my opinion.

I agree that the use of the half-letters should be left to the discretion of the writer and not automatically inserted by the driver.  However, I do not agree with you that the half-letters should be relegated to  word art or special effects on the computer.  The half-letters make quite distinctive word outlines that appeal to me greatly.  After much use of QS, I feel confident in saying that they are no harder to read and are automatically interpreted by the eye and brain in an appropriate fashion.  In fact, they might even be easier to read quickly since I believe automatic word recognition, i.e. without having to break the word down into its constituent letters for deciphering, is facilitated by unique word-shapes.  In any event, I feel a person who wishes to use half-letters in his computer writing should be free to do so if he chooses.  If other people are put off by this or find it harder to read, the writer will find it out by their comments to him.

Your approach to the traditionally-written digraph letters will be quite easy to learn.  By the way, when I printed your proposed remapping out, in place of Quikscript tall and deep "x," I got the letter "e."  One with an accent aigu and one with accent grave.  Any idea why this occurred?  (As I told you previously, I have not used "x"  in writing in Jerome as I felt their inclusion in the alphabet somewhat incongruous with Quikscript's rationale so I had not had this occur previously in my writing.)

Here is a problem I have noticed:  If we type "th", for example, in the word "hothouse," how does the driver know this should not be a "thoth" but two separate letters?  Admittedly, I doubt this would be a common occurrence, but we should have a way to deal with it.  There are probably other English words that would cause similar problems that we are not aware of yet.

Could we somehow tell the driver to ignore the apparently flagged character when it was inappropriately triggered?  Could there be an "undo" key that, if input immediately after the inappropriate flagged character, signals the driver to correct the two preceding keystrokes to their normal outputs rather than interpreting them as a flagged character?  Perhaps the "<" character could be used, suggesting by its shape that the flagged character should be opened back up to the two separate characters that were input.

As I had proposed before, mapping the half-letters as flagged characters on the same primary keys, i.e. half-tot on the "t" key and mapping "Whitewheat" to "q" seems felicitous to me as it is logical and will foster quick learning of the mapping.

You commented in  your post of 24 Feb.,  that you love the ligature letters.  I also find them very attractive.  Rather than discarding them out of hand as you proposed due to the apparent scarcity of available spots on the keyboard,  I would suggest the following:  map the ligatures to the number keys at the top of the keyboard and trigger their output with the "j" flag.  In this manner the numbers and their normal shift characters would still work, people who do not want to use the ligatures could ignore them, and those of us who revel in their curvaceous appearance can enjoy them in our writing.   This sounds like a win-win solution to me!  I would map them to numbers 3 - 9 as this avoids the use of the left hand little finger, which is weaker and shorter.  To extend this one last step:  the two Gaelic letters could be mapped to "1" and "0," where they would bother no one, but would be available for Scottish writers.  Since the use of these letters would be minimal, having to access them with right and left little fingers should not be too much of a strain.

Another difficulty I see with your proposal is  in connection with the vowels not mapped to a single key.  I agree with the suggestion that they be mapped with a flag that apes the typical spelling in traditional orthography as this would simplify learning the mapping.  However, we probably need a test period to see how well the proposed letter combinations will work in actuality.

The driver will interpret the first letter typed as a standard QS letter until the "flag" letter is typed so we have to insure that our flag does not duplicate a pattern that normally occurs in English.  As an example, you proposed
the combination "ah" for the character "Ah.  But what if you are trying to type the word "ahead."  You need a schwa followed by an "h," but the driver will interpret this as an "Ah."  Again, the idea of an "undo" character as I suggested above would  solve this (if that is technically feasible), or we need to map another letter combination for "Ah."  I have not given much thought to the other proposed letter combinations for these vowels, but I would not be surprised if they also could give rise to unexpected results.

Let me know your thoughts on this.

Thanks for your work, Jon.

Sincerely,
 

Paige
